compositeCheatsheet.name: 006 Writing your first test with JavaFX

taskGroup.name: Creating and executing your first test with JavaFX
taskGroup.intro:
These cheat sheets take you step-by-step through your first test with JavaFX.
The requirements for the program we want to test are as follows:
1. A small calculator which can perform an addition
2. There will be two text entry areas and an equals button
3. The result of the addition will be shown in the interface
Your task is to create a test which will test this functionality via the GUI.
Make sure that the Integrated Test Environment (ITE) is maximized to complete these cheat sheets!

taskGroup.name: Working with the cheat sheets
taskGroup.intro: This task gives you a quick introduction to working with the cheat sheets.

task.name: Navigating through the cheat sheets
task.onCompletion: Once a task is done, you can either review it or click to move to the next task.

taskGroup.name: Setting up the Project
taskGroup.intro: This group of tasks deals with creating a Project, and adding and configuring an AUT.

task.name: Create a Project
task.intro: A Project contains information about the AUT and also contains the Test Cases to test the AUT.
task.onCompletion: You will notice that there is a category of blue Test Cases in the Test Case browser. This is a pre-defined library of Test Cases to make test creation easier. We will use these later to create the test.

task.name: Define an AUT
task.intro: Each Project can have one or more AUT's.

task.name: Configure the AUT
task.intro:
Each AUT can have one or more configurations.
A configuration contains details about how to start the AUT.
For example, you need to define where to start your AUT (on what computer) and with what arguments.
Some AUT's will need different configurations so that they can be tested on different platforms.
task.onCompletion:
It may be necessary to change or add other information in the AUT configuration dialog when you configure your own AUT - especially if you are working with the AUT on another machine.
There is more information on configuring AUT's in the handbook, in the Tasks chapter.
You can also see context-sensitive help by pressing F1 in the AUT configuration dialog.

taskGroup.name: Creating the test specification
taskGroup.intro: This group of tasks deals with Test Case creation.
taskGroup.onCompletion: You have now seen how easy it is to create tests using the library we installed.

task.name: Create a Test Case
task.intro:
Now you will create a Test Case to make the program perform an addition and check the result.
Test Cases are reusable modules.
Note that the following steps are all completed based on the requirements for the AUT - we are not dependent on the AUT to create tests.

task.name: Reference Test Cases from the library
task.intro: The majority of actions you will require to write tests are already in the library of reused Test Cases.
task.onCompletion: This task has shown you how to use the library of Test Cases to create tests. Test Cases are not copied, they are referenced. You always only have one source - which makes maintainability easier later.

task.name: Add data
task.intro: Now that the test specification is ready, data can be added to the Test Case.
task.onCompletion: The benefit of adding the data here is that it is separate from the test flow. It can easily be changed, read from a central test data set, or translated.

taskGroup.name: Preparing for execution
taskGroup.intro: This group of tasks shows you how to add Test Cases to a Test Suite to be executed, and also tell you how to start the AUT Agent.

task.name: Create and fill a Test Suite
task.intro: Test Suites are the executable units.

task.name: Open the object mapping editor
task.intro: The object mapping editor is where you manage the object (GUI) map.

task.name: Start and connect to the AUT Agent
task.intro:
You can use the embedded AUT Agent to run tests locally on the same machine as the ITE.
To perform distributed testing, you can install and start the separate AUT Agent on each machine you want to run tests on.

task.name: Start the AUT
task.intro: The AUT must be started in order to object map and execute the tests.

taskGroup.name: Object Mapping
taskGroup.intro:
Up until now, the test specification has been separate from the actual AUT.
Now the AUT can be joined with the specification so that the test can be executed.

task.name: Object Mapping
task.intro: Object mapping involves collecting the components you want to test from the running AUT and assigning them to the component names you used in the test.

taskGroup.name: Executing the test
taskGroup.intro: This group of tasks shows you how to execute a test.

task.name: Execute the test
task.intro: The test can now be executed.
